comment.text: This key displays the text "Who has access" as a label within an access selector block, likely in a dialog or panel where users manage link permissions. It's used to clearly indicate what the following options pertain to – the individuals or groups who currently have access.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Azerbaijani translation "Kimə giriş var" literally translates to "Who has access?" but might not be the most natural or idiomatic way to phrase this question in Azerbaijani. While understandable, a more nuanced translation might be preferable.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider alternatives like "Kim daxil ola bilir?" (Who can log in?) or "Kimə icazə var?" (Who has permission?)

ai_spell_check_issues.description: While "Ով ունի մուտքի իրավունք" is a literal translation, it's a bit clunky and formal for the simple phrase "Who has access". A more natural and common translation would be "Ուզում եմ իմանալ ով ունի մուտք" or simply "Ով ունի մուտք".
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider using "Ով ունի մուտք" or "Ուզում եմ իմանալ ով ունի մուտք" for a more natural feel.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: While "アクセスできるユーザー" (akusesu dekiru yūzā) is a possible translation, it's quite literal and verbose for "Who has access." A more natural and concise translation would be something like "アクセス権限を持つ人" (akusesu kenmei o motsu hito) or simply "アクセス権限" (akusesu kenmei).
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider "アクセス権限を持つ人" or "アクセス権限".

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Lao translation "ໃຜມີການເຂົ້າເຖິງ" is a literal translation and sounds slightly awkward in Lao. A more natural phrasing would be preferred.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: ໃຜສາມາດເຂົ້າໄດ້

ai_spell_check_issues.description: While "Ко има приступ" is understandable, a more natural and idiomatic translation of "Who has access" would be "Ко има дозволу" or "Ко може да приступи". "Приступ" often implies physical access rather than authorization.
While "谁拥有访问权限" is technically correct, it's a bit formal and verbose for the English phrase "Who has access." A more natural and common translation would be more concise.
